articles.headline: Transgender Inmate’s Hormone Treatment Lawsuit Gets Justice Dept. Backing
articles.snippet: The inmate, who is in prison in Georgia, wants the state to restart the hormone treatment she had been taking for 17 years before her arrest.
articles.abstract: The inmate, who is in prison in Georgia, wants the state to restart the hormone treatment she had been taking for 17 years before her arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department put the nation’s prisons and jails on notice on Friday that it regarded blanket policies prohibiting new hormone treatment for transgender inmates to be unconstitutional.

articles.headline: As Quakes Rattle Oklahoma, Fingers Point to Oil and Gas Industry
articles.snippet: Some in the industry believe the earthquakes are a natural phenomenon, but many scientists disagree.
articles.abstract: Some in the industry believe the earthquakes are a natural phenomenon, but many scientists disagree.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE, Okla. — Yanked without warning from a deep sleep, Jennifer Lin Cooper, whose family has lived near here for more than a half-century, could think only that the clamor enveloping her house was coming from a helicopter landing on her roof. She was wrong.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Powdered Alcohol Meets Resistance in U.S. Before It Even Comes to Market
articles.snippet: Concerned over the potential for abuse, six states have banned the product, and a senator has introduced a bill to ban its sale and manufacture nationwide.
articles.abstract: Concerned over the potential for abuse, six states have banned the product, and a senator has introduced a bill to ban its sale and manufacture nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2012, Mark Phillips needed a way to market his new invention: a powdered form of alcohol that could be mixed with water.

articles.headline: ‘Mad Men’ and the Era that Changed Advertising
articles.snippet: While Don Draper wouldn’t recognize much of today’s advertising business, which is increasingly driven by technology, big personalities at the very top continue to reign.
articles.abstract: While Don Draper wouldn’t recognize much of today’s advertising business, which is increasingly driven by technology, big personalities at the very top continue to reign.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Champagne toasts on a rooftop overlooking the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, John D. Wren and Maurice Lévy celebrated the $35 billion merger between their two advertising companies, Omnicom Group and Publicis Groupe. The trans-Atlantic deal was the largest ever in the industry, uniting the world’s second- and third-largest advertising groups to create a new global leader that would dethrone their archrival, Martin Sorrell’s WPP.

articles.headline: An Iran Nuclear Deal Built on Coffee, All-Nighters and Compromise
articles.snippet: In hashing out one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history, Iran and the United States took a simple approach: stay in the same hotel room until they figure out how to get along.
articles.abstract: In hashing out one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history, Iran and the United States took a simple approach: stay in the same hotel room until they figure out how to get along.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — It was just one of hundreds of arguments between American and Iranian officials as they tried to hash out what may prove to be one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history. But it spoke volumes about how two countries that so deeply distrust each other managed to strike a tentative deal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Jay Edelson, the Class-Action Lawyer Who May Be Tech’s Least Friended Man
articles.snippet: The class-action lawyer, who specializes in filing privacy lawsuits against technology companies, has raised the ire of Silicon Valley executives.
articles.abstract: The class-action lawyer, who specializes in filing privacy lawsuits against technology companies, has raised the ire of Silicon Valley executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: When technology executives imagine the boogeyman, they see a baby-face guy in wire-rim glasses. His name is Jay Edelson.

articles.headline: G.O.P.’s Israel Support Deepens as Political Contributions Shift
articles.snippet: Republicans are more fervently pro-Israel than ever, partly a result of ideology, but also a product of a surge in campaign spending on their behalf by a small group of wealthy donors.
articles.abstract: Republicans are more fervently pro-Israel than ever, partly a result of ideology, but also a product of a surge in campaign spending on their behalf by a small group of wealthy donors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the proposed agreement over Iran’s nuclear program is debated in coming weeks, President Obama will make his case to a Congress controlled by Republicans who are more fervently pro-Israel than ever, partly a result of ideology, but also a product of a surge in donations and campaign spending on their behalf by a small group of wealthy donors.

articles.headline: California Drought Tests History of Endless Growth
articles.snippet: A punishing drought is forcing a reconsideration of whether the aspiration of untrammeled growth that has for so long been the state’s engine has run against the limits of nature.
articles.abstract: A punishing drought is forcing a reconsideration of whether the aspiration of untrammeled growth that has for so long been the state’s engine has run against the limits of nature.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For more than a century, California has been the state where people flocked for a better life — 164,000 square miles of mountains, farmland and coastline, shimmering with ambition and dreams, money and beauty. It was the cutting-edge symbol of possibility: Hollywood, Silicon Valley, aerospace, agriculture and vineyards.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Jack Healy and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Victims of Financial Wrongdoing Need a More Muscular S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The regulator lacks the power to extract fines equal to the losses of harmed investors, often making class-action suits their best recourse.
articles.abstract: The regulator lacks the power to extract fines equal to the losses of harmed investors, often making class-action suits their best recourse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the many billions of dollars financial companies have paid in regulatory and legal settlements related to the mortgage crisis, how much money has actually found its way into the pockets of investors harmed by their actions?

articles.headline: Private Eyes in the Grocery Aisles
articles.snippet: Food suppliers, manufacturers and markets depend on testing companies like IEH Laboratories to find contaminated products and to root out fraud.
articles.abstract: Food suppliers, manufacturers and markets depend on testing companies like IEH Laboratories to find contaminated products and to root out fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mansour Samadpour makes his way through the supermarket like a detective working a crime scene, slow, watchful, up one aisle and down the next. A clerk mistakenly assumes that he needs help, but Mr. Samadpour brushes him off. He knows exactly what he’s doing.

articles.headline: ‘Gertie’s Babies,’ Sold at Birth, Use DNA to Unlock Secret Past
articles.snippet: Gertrude Pitkanen Van Orden delivered and sold babies, and mostly evaded legal consequence, in Montana from the 1920s through the 1950s.
articles.abstract: Gertrude Pitkanen Van Orden delivered and sold babies, and mostly evaded legal consequence, in Montana from the 1920s through the 1950s.
articles.lead_paragraph: COEUR D’ALENE, Idaho — Sue Docken’s start in life, in 1951, with a no-questions-asked cash adoption at the hands of a midwife, had strong elements of the crime scene that it was.

articles.headline: Jeb Bush as Inevitable Choice? Republicans Say Not So Fast
articles.snippet: Three months into what allies once called a “shock and awe” drive to dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.
articles.abstract: Three months into what allies once called a “shock and awe” drive to dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three months into what allies once confidently described as a “shock and awe” drive to overcome his rivals and dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: A Norway Town and Its Pipeline to Jihad in Syria
articles.snippet: After at least eight young men from a single neighborhood in Norway left for Syria, local officials were left pondering: Why it is that certain areas generate a disproportionate number of jihadists?
articles.abstract: After at least eight young men from a single neighborhood in Norway left for Syria, local officials were left pondering: Why it is that certain areas generate a disproportionate number of jihadists?
articles.lead_paragraph: FREDRIKSTAD, Norway — The real trouble started when they stopped causing trouble. Torleif Sanchez Hammer and his friends — all residents of the same small cluster of clapboard houses in southern Norway — had been having run-ins with the police for years but then suddenly halted their marijuana-fueled gatherings in the basement apartment of Mr. Hammer’s widowed mother.

articles.headline: China Escalates Hollywood Partnerships, Aiming to Compete One Day
articles.snippet: Chinese studios are helping develop, design and produce world-class animated features and have ambitions to go global with their own.
articles.abstract: Chinese studios are helping develop, design and produce world-class animated features and have ambitions to go global with their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Tucked away in a quiet design studio in this fast-growing city, a team of young animators, illustrators and computer programmers is bringing an ancient Chinese village to digital life.

articles.headline: Comcast Recruits Its Beneficiaries to Lobby for Time Warner Deal
articles.snippet: Many letters to the government in support of the $45 billion deal are from groups that have received charitable or political donations from Comcast.
articles.abstract: Many letters to the government in support of the $45 billion deal are from groups that have received charitable or political donations from Comcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The letters have come from all around the United States — from the Nutmeg Big Brothers and Big Sisters in Connecticut, the Houston Area Urban League and even the Dan Marino Foundation in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. — some praising the Comcast Corporation, others urging the federal government to stand aside and approve Comcast’s proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable.

articles.headline: President Obama Calls Preliminary Iran Nuclear Deal ‘Our Best Bet’
articles.snippet: In an interview, President Obama called last week’s preliminary agreement a “once in a lifetime opportunity” to curb the spread of nuclear weapons in a dangerous region while reassuring critics.
articles.abstract: In an interview, President Obama called last week’s preliminary agreement a “once in a lifetime opportunity” to curb the spread of nuclear weapons in a dangerous region while reassuring critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama strongly defended last week’s preliminary agreement with Iran as a “once in a lifetime opportunity” to curb the spread of nuclear weapons in a dangerous region while reassuring critics that he would keep all options available if Tehran ultimately cheated.

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Article on Rape at University of Virginia Failed All Basics, Report Says
articles.snippet: Rolling Stone retracted its article about a brutal gang rape after the release of a report that cataloged a series of errors at the magazine.
articles.abstract: Rolling Stone retracted its article about a brutal gang rape after the release of a report that cataloged a series of errors at the magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone magazine retracted its article about a brutal gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity after the release of a report on Sunday that concluded the widely discredited piece was the result of failures at every stage of the process.

articles.headline: In Report on Rolling Stone, a Case Study in Failed Journalism
articles.snippet: With “A Rape on Campus,” Rolling Stone’s widely discredited article, traditional safeguards broke down at pretty much every level of the editorial process.
articles.abstract: With “A Rape on Campus,” Rolling Stone’s widely discredited article, traditional safeguards broke down at pretty much every level of the editorial process.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Rolling Stone took the unusual step of bringing in Steve Coll, the Pulitzer Prize-winning dean of America’s most prestigious journalism school, to dissect its widely discredited article on campus rape, the magazine was clearly making a statement. It was going to get to the bottom of this mess.

articles.headline: RadioShack’s Blueprint for a Rebirth, Planned by a Hedge Fund
articles.snippet: Standard General, which will take over 1,700 of the 4,000 RadioShack stores, said that eliminating the retailer’s heavy cost structure and some old business practices left a core worth saving.
articles.abstract: Standard General, which will take over 1,700 of the 4,000 RadioShack stores, said that eliminating the retailer’s heavy cost structure and some old business practices left a core worth saving.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after RadioShack’s narrow escape from liquidation in bankruptcy court, Soohyung Kim, the financier who led the contentious rescue, retreated to a back office to make a conference call with the chain’s almost 2,700 workers, vendors and landlords.

articles.headline: Battling Crime and Calories at F.B.I. (Fit Bureau of Investigation)
articles.snippet: New fitness tests are in part a response to increasing concerns of senior F.B.I. officials about the toll on agents after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.abstract: New fitness tests are in part a response to increasing concerns of senior F.B.I. officials about the toll on agents after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents are on the front lines of the fight to protect the United States from Islamic terrorists, Russian hackers and Chinese spies.

articles.headline: Online Test-Takers Feel Anti-Cheating Software’s Uneasy Glare
articles.snippet: School administrators say for online learning to be legitimate, testing has to be monitored. Proctortrack is a new anti-cheating program being used by some universities.
articles.abstract: School administrators say for online learning to be legitimate, testing has to be monitored. Proctortrack is a new anti-cheating program being used by some universities.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Before Betsy Chao, a senior here at Rutgers University, could take midterm exams in her online courses this semester, her instructors sent emails directing students to download Proctortrack, a new anti-cheating technology.

articles.headline: Bulgaria Puts Up a New Wall, but This One Keeps People Out
articles.snippet: The former Communist nation has completed 20 miles of fence along its border with Turkey, and plans to extend it to 100 miles, to stem the flow of refugees.
articles.abstract: The former Communist nation has completed 20 miles of fence along its border with Turkey, and plans to extend it to 100 miles, to stem the flow of refugees.
articles.lead_paragraph: LESOVO, Bulgaria — Less than two decades after the painstaking removal of a massive border fence designed to keep people in, Bulgarian authorities are just as painstakingly building a new fence along the rugged Turkish border, this time to keep people out.

articles.headline: Transgender Woman Cites Attacks and Abuse in Men’s Prison
articles.snippet: On the day she arrived at a Georgia prison intake center, the deliberate defeminizing of Ashley Diamond, a male-to-female transgender woman, began.
articles.abstract: On the day she arrived at a Georgia prison intake center, the deliberate defeminizing of Ashley Diamond, a male-to-female transgender woman, began.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, Ga. — Before she fell on hard times and got into trouble with the law, Ashley Diamond had a wardrobe of wigs named after her favorite divas. “Darling, hand me Aretha” or Mariah or Madonna, she would say to her younger sister when they glammed up to go out on the town.

articles.headline: Boeing and Delta Spend Millions in Fight Over Export-Import Bank’s Existence
articles.snippet: A battle between two aviation heavyweights over an obscure bank masks a political war between opponents of “corporate welfare” and major business groups.
articles.abstract: A battle between two aviation heavyweights over an obscure bank masks a political war between opponents of “corporate welfare” and major business groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last week, with little notice, a federal judge here tossed out Delta Air Lines’ longstanding claim that the government’s export credit agency — which, among other things, provides loan guarantees to overseas airlines for the purchase of Boeing jets — was helping international competitors at the airline’s expense.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Eric Lipton
